item.title: Russians Hacked Two U.S. State Election Systems
item.dc:creator: Robert Windrem and William M. Arkin and Ken Dilanian
item.description: Officials are concerned that the Russians are attempting to interfere in the U.S. election and sow doubt about the electoral process.

item.title: Who Is Huma Abedin? Clinton's Embattled Right-Hand Woman
item.dc:creator: Irin Carmon
item.description: As befits a close aide of Hillary Clinton, the world's most scrutinized woman, everything about Huma Abedin projects privacy and discretion.

media:content.media:text: Image: Huma Abedin
media:content.media:description: U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton (R) receives a note from her aide Huma Abedin (L) as she testifies about the State Department's FY2012 budget during a hearing of the State, Foreign Operations and Related Programs Subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee in the Rayburn House Office Building on March 10, 2011 in Washington, DC.
Huma Abedin and Anthony Weiner attend the 12th annual CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Awards at Spring Studios on Nov. 2, 2015 in New York.

item.title: Pro-Trump Pastor Defends Blackface Tweet, Then Deletes it
item.description: Burns deleted the tweet and put up a video post with the caption, "I want to Apologize for my Twit (sic) that many found to be offensive."

media:content.media:text: Image: Donald Trump presidential campaign, Austin, USA - 23 Aug 2016
media:content.media:description: Pastor Mark Burns speaks at Donald Trump presidential campaign rally in Austin, Texas on Aug. 23, 2016.

item.title: Actor Gene Wilder Dies at 83
item.dc:creator: Corky Siemaszko and The Associated Press
item.description: Wilder's nephew said Monday that the actor and writer died earlier this month in Stamford, Connecticut from complications from Alzheimer's disease.

media:content.media:description: American actor Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka in 'Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory', directed by Mel Stuart, 1971.

media:content.media:description: American actor Gene Wilder as Willy Wonka in 'Willy Wonka & The Chocolate Factory', directed by Mel Stuart, 1971.

item.title: McDonald's Employee with Down Syndrome Retires After 32 Years
item.description: A Massachusetts resident who has Down Syndrome received a touching send-off when she retired from her job at a McDonald's in Needham.

item.title: African-Americans in the South Face New Barriers to Vote
item.dc:creator: Max Garland and Alex Amico and Ali Schmitz and Phillip Jackson and Pam Ortega/News21
item.description: A wave of new voting laws has emerged in the Southern states, potentially disenfranchising a large percentage of unregistered African-Americans.

media:content.media:description: The Edmund Pettus Bridge was the site of Bloody Sunday, where more than 50 people were hospitalized after they were beaten and hit with tear gas by law enforcement officers. (Pinar Istek/News21)

Joanne Bland stands in front of the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma. Bland was the youngest marcher on Bloody Sunday at just 11 years old. She now revisits the bridge when she gives historical tours of Selma. (Jeffrey Pierre/News21)

Lula Hatcher said the right to vote transformed her community during the 1960s. Her friend Annie Lee Cooper, was the civil rights activist who punched Selma Sheriff Jim Clark and was played by Oprah Winfrey in the recent film "Selma." Cooper stayed with Hatcher in her home until the day she died. (Jeffrey Pierre/News21)
Tuskegee Mayor Johnny Ford sits in front of a wall of photographs in his office. Ford said the wall is a mix of professional and personal mementos. (Jeffrey Pierre/News21)

VJ's Cutz and Styles is one of the many African-American-owned businesses near Macon's historic Cotton Avenue. Cotton Avenue is now divided between two districts after the city of Macon and Bibb County consolidated in 2014, leading many African-American leaders to say it's weakening minority voting power in the community. (Phillip Jackson/News21)

David Lucas has served the East Macon area as a state senator since 2012. In his childhood, he said he had a near-death experience that inspired him to pursue a political career. (Phillip Jackson/News21)

A civil rights mural in downtown Durham, North Carolina, commemorates various civil rights moments in Durham's history, including a sit-in at the Royal Ice Cream parlor and the integration of its public schools. Community funding helped push the creation of the mural in 2015. (Phillip Jackson/News21)

item.title: Mold Threatens to Leave More Flooded Louisianans Homeless
item.dc:creator: Alex Johnson
item.description: Doctors and government health officials alike say mold removal is best done by licensed contractors, because the danger to homeowners is just too great.

media:content.media:text: Image: Mold remediation in Prairieville, La., home
media:content.media:description: Vince Carr uses a spray to prevent mold growth in one of his four homes after flooding in Prairieville, La.

media:content.media:credit: U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media:content.media:description: Vince Carr uses a spray to prevent mold growth in one of his four homes after flooding in Prairieville, La.

item.title: Airport False Alarms Expose Danger of Chaotic Evacuations
item.dc:creator: Jon Schuppe
item.description: Three times since June, a major American airport has been evacuated due to unfounded threats, sending people fleeing into streets and airfields.

media:content.media:text: Image:
media:content.media:description: Passengers pull their luggage as they walk toward Los Angeles International Airport on Aug. 28, when reports of a gunman turned out to be false.

media:content.media:text: Image: Delayed passengers inside Terminal 7 at Los Angeles International Airport go through TSA security check following a false alarm event in Los Angeles
media:content.media:description: Delayed passengers inside Terminal 7 at Los Angeles International Airport line up to go through TSA security check following a false alarm on Aug. 28.

item.title: Huma Abedin Leaving Weiner Amid New Sexting Scandal
item.dc:creator: Monica Alba and Elisha Fieldstadt and Adam Reiss
item.description: 'After long and painful consideration and work on my marriage, I have made the decision to separate from my husband,' Abedin said in a statement.

item.title: Alleged Sex Offender Found in Louisiana With Missing Kids
item.dc:creator: Tim Stelloh
item.description: Joseph Moreno, 37, was arrested at an interstate convenience store west of New Orleans. Four children, all listed as missing in California, were found in a car outside the store.

item.title: Hikers Travel 72 Miles to Fight Parkinson's
item.description: Hikers completed a grueling 72-mile journey through Washington state to raise awareness and money for Parkinson's research. KING's Sula Kim reports.

item.title: FBI Offers $50K Reward for Capture of Fugitive Polygamist
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: The feds hope a $50,000 reward, coupled with a falling out between polygamist fugitive Lyle Jeffs and his brother, will lead to his capture.

item.title: 'Lucy' Fell From a Tree, Study Finds
item.dc:creator: Maggie Fox
item.description: Maybe she was sleeping high up, or maybe she climbed up after some juicy fruit. New evidence shows pre-human 'Lucy' died falling out of a tall tree.

media:content.media:description: a, Lucy. b, c, Right humerus (b, top: stereo, superior, medial up; bottom: lateral; c, stereo, posterior) preserves valgus head-shattering four-part proximal fracture.
The researchers hypothesize that Lucy fell from a tall tree, landing feet-first and twisting to the right, with arrows indicating the sequence and types of fractures.

item.title: Bizarre Lightning Strike Kills Hundreds of Reindeer
item.description: Hundreds of dead reindeer littered a plateau in Norway, apparently killed by lightning.

item.title: Paris Attacks Inspire Huge Influx of Police Recruits
item.dc:creator: Mac William Bishop
item.description: Earning a slot at the Police Nationale's academy is now as competitive as applying to one of France's top universities.

media:content.media:text: Image: Ceremony at France's National Police College on June 24, 2016
media:content.media:description: Newly promoted officers stand guard during a ceremony at the National Police College in Saint-Cyr-au-Mont-D???Or, France, on June 24, 2016.

media:content.media:text: Image: Clarissa Jean-Philippe and Ahmed Merabet
media:content.media:description: Police officers Clarissa Jean-Philippe and Ahmed Merabet were among those killed by the Charlie Hebdo attackers.

media:content.media:text: Image: Burned buses in Trappes, France
media:content.media:description: Police officers investigate near the wreckage of 27 buses burned by rampaging youths in Trappes, France, on Nov. 4, 2005.

media:content.media:text: Image: Ceremony at France's National Police College on June 24, 2016
media:content.media:description: Officers stand guard during a ceremony at the National Police College in Saint-Cyr-au-Mont-d'Or, France, on June 24.

media:content.media:text: Image: French police officer falls during protest against labor reforms in Paris on June 14, 2016
media:content.media:description: A French riot police officer falls next to colleagues during a demonstration in Paris against proposed labor reforms on June 14. Several hundred masked protesters hurled objects at police, authorities said.

media:content.media:text: Image: Burning police car in Paris on May 18, 2016
media:content.media:description: A police car burns after being set alight on May 18. Two officers were inside the vehicle when it was torched.
